div.l: This ioly prentys / with his Maister bood
Tyl he were nygh out of his prentishood
Al were he snybbed / erly and late
And somtyme lad / wᵗith revel to Newgate
But atte laste / his maist̉er hym bithoughte
Vpon a day / whan he / his paper soughte
Of a prouerbe / that seith this same worde
Wel bet is roten appil out of horde
Than that that it rote al the remenant
So fareth by a riotous seruant
It is fulle lasse harme / to late hym pace
Than he shende alle the seruᵃauntes in the place
Therfore his Maist̉er / ȝaf hym a quytance
And bad hym goon with sorowe and meschance
And thus this ioly p̉rentys hadde his leve
Now let hym /riote / al the nyght or leve
And for ther is no theef withoute a lowke
That helpeth hym / to wasten and to sowke
Of that he bribe can̄ / or borwe may
Anoon he sente his bed / and his aray
Vnto a conpere of his owne sort
That loved dys revel / and disport
And hadde a wyf that heeld for countenᵃaunce
A shoppe / and swyued for hir sustenᵃaunce
But here of I wol passe as now
And of yonge Gamelyn I wol telle yow
Litheth and lesteneth and herkeneth aright
And ye shul here of a doughty knyght
Sir Iohn of Boundes was his name
He coude of norture and of moche game
Thre sones þe knyght hadde ⁊and wᵗith his body hem wan
The oldest was a moche shrewe and sone he bigan
His bretherne loued wel her fader and of hym were agast
The oldest deserved his Fader curs and had it atte last
The goode knyght his Fader lyued so ȝore
That deth was comen hym to and handeled hym ful sore
The goode knyght cared sore sike there he lay
How his children shulde lyue after his day
